title: The most difficult holes in the PGA over the last 5 years.
text:
The PGA Tour is halfway through its 2024 season. From January to August, professional golfers from all over the world compete in tournaments throughout the tour. Each tournament takes place at a golf course with a total of 18 holes lasting a couple of days.
Professional golfers make money off of their winnings at each tournament. Unlike other professional athletes, PGA golfers do not earn a salary. This creates high stakes on the PGA Tour for professionals to win in order to make money.
With a better understanding of the stakes professional golfers compete for, a question is asked. Over the last 5 years, which holes have given the professionals the most trouble on the PGA Tour?
Any of these holes can make or break a professional’s dream of money and a first-place finish.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR)
  )

BadPar4 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 4.3, YARDS < 430) 

BadPar5 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 5.0, YARDS < 550)

BadPar3 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 3.5, YARDS < 230)

BadP4 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 4.6, YARDS < 500)

Bad <- bind_rows(BadPar4,BadPar5,BadPar3, BadP4)

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=PGA, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_smooth(data=PGA, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), method="lm") +
  geom_point(data=Bad, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), color="red") +
  geom_text_repel(data=Bad, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG, label=HoleYear)) +
  labs(
    x="Total Yards", 
    y="Average Score", 
    title="Scorecards Turn Ugly", 
    subtitle="Over the last 5 years, dreams die when professional golfers play these holes.",
    caption="Source: PGATour.com | By Mason Dover"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Golfers did not score well on any of these holes. Hole 18 at The Renaissance Club in 2022 became a burden at the tour. Golfers shot almost a full stroke over par at this hole, making it the hardest hole in the 2022 PGA Tour.
Distance plays a role in a hole’s difficulty, but what do those results look like?
Every par puts expectations on the professionals. To win a tournament, golfers need to score low on each hole.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR), 
    Difficulty = AVG - PAR...4
  )

top20 <- PGA |> top_n(20, wt=Difficulty)


ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(data=top20, aes(y=reorder(HoleYear, DBLBOGEY), x=BIRDIE, xend=DBLBOGEY),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="The Top 20 Holes Based on the Difference Between the Scoring Average on the Hole and Par", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>birdies</span> are on the left, that's good. If <span style = 'color:red;'>double bogeys</span> are on the right, that's bad.",
    x="Birdies vs Double Bogeys", 
    y="",
    caption="Source: PGATour.com | By Mason Dover"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









A hole may have a lot of double bogeys, but that does not mean it is challenging. Some holes, like Oak Hill Country Club’s East Course Hole 6 in 2023, have many birdies and double bogeys in the results.
Golfers struggled on Hole 18 of The Renaissance Club in 2022. Players were unable to score many birdies and ended up shooting a lot more double bogeys. 
Now that distance and score have been determined as factors in difficulty, how can golfers decide which holes are the hardest? 
The location of every hole and the expected par increases the stakes, which can make things difficult as the game goes on.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR), 
    Difficulty = AVG - PAR...4
  )

top10 <- PGA |> top_n(10, wt=Difficulty)

HardTop10 <- top10 |>
  select(HoleYear, PAR...4, AVG, Difficulty)

HardTop10 |>
  gt() |>
    cols_label(
    HoleYear = "PGA Courses",
    PAR...4 = "Par",
    AVG = "Avg"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Challenges in the Back Half",
    subtitle = "Par 4's provide the most difficulty to professional golfers, but a couple par 3's sneak their way into the top 10." 
  ) |>
tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Mason Dover  |  **Source:** PGATour.com")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=15)
     )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  fmt_percent(
    columns = c(Difficulty),
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#98FB98"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = HoleYear == "17 Ocean Course at Kiawah Island 2021")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#98FB98"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = HoleYear == "16 Muirfield Village Golf Course 2020")
  )









Challenges in the Back Half


Par 4's provide the most difficulty to professional golfers, but a couple par 3's sneak their way into the top 10.


PGA Courses
Par
Avg
Difficulty




6 Oak Hill Country Club - East Course 2023
4
4.519
51.9%


18 The Renaissance Club 2022
4
4.617
61.7%


18 TPC Sawgrass 2022
4
4.530
53.0%


11 TPC Potomac at Avenel Farm 2022
4
4.489
48.9%


11 Augusta National Golf Club 2022
4
4.477
47.7%


17 St. Andrews Links (Old Course) 2022
4
4.456
45.6%


17 Ocean Course at Kiawah Island 2021
3
3.531
53.1%


18 Bay Hill Club & Lodge 2021
4
4.464
46.4%


18 Quail Hollow Club 2021
4
4.456
45.6%


18 GC of Houston 2020
4
4.501
50.1%


16 Muirfield Village Golf Course 2020
3
3.468
46.8%



By: Mason Dover | Source: PGATour.com









While some may expect par 5’s to challenge professionals the most, it is the opposite.
With fewer strokes to work with, professionals need to make every shot count. Each hole’s distance also plays a big factor in which club a golfer needs to use. That explains hole 17 at Ocean Course at Kiawah Island in 2021 and hole 16 at Muirfield Village Golf Course in 2020’s difficulty.
Each professional golfer faces adversity on the golf course. There are many challenges on each hole that make or break players. The weather, sand traps and mental pressure are just a few. 
In the next 5 years, these factors will determine which holes cause the most trouble on the PGA Tour.

title: Post With Code

title: Kawhi Leonard’s Impact on the Toronto Raptors
text:
After the Cleveland Cavaliers swept the Toronto Raptors in the second round of the 2018 NBA Playoffs, something needed to change. On July 18, 2018, the Raptors traded DeMar DeRozen, Jakob Poeltl and a 2019 first-round pick to the San Antonio Spurs for Kawhi Leonard and Danny Green.
Toronto traded away their best player, DeMar DeRozen, and took a chance on Kawhi. Leonard sustained a right quadriceps injury the season prior, limiting him to 9 total games.
The injury did not hold Kawhi back and the Toronto Raptors had another great year. The Raptors overcame a second round exit and ended up winning their first NBA Championship.
Even though Kawhi only spent one year with the Raptors, how much of an impact did he have on the Toronto Raptors?
NBA Regular Season games determine which teams qualify for the Playoffs. Coming off of an amazing career with the Spurs, Kawhi needed to show the Raptors what he could do.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbump)
library(ggtext)
library(gt)

NBATeams <- read_csv("NBAData - NBATeamFinish.csv")

Spurs <- NBATeams |>
  filter(Team == "San Antonio Spurs") |>
  filter(Season == "2011-12" | Season == "2012-13" | Season == "2013-14" | Season == "2014-15" | Season == "2015-16" | Season == "2016-17" | Season == "2017-18")

Raptors <- NBATeams |>
  filter(Team == "Toronto Raptors") |>
  filter(Season == "2018-19")

Clippers <- NBATeams |>
  filter(Team == "Los Angeles Clippers") |>
  filter(Season == "2019-20" | Season == "2020-21" | Season == "2021-22" | Season == "2022-23" | Season == "2023-24")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bump(data=NBATeams, aes(x=Season, y=Rk, group=Team), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=NBATeams, aes(x=Season, y=Rk), color = "lightgrey", size = 4) +
  geom_bump(data=Spurs, aes(x=Season, y=Rk, group=Team), color="black") +
  geom_point(data=Spurs, aes(x=Season, y=Rk), color = "black", size = 4) +
  geom_point(data=Raptors, aes(x=Season, y=Rk), color = "#CE1141", size = 4) +
  geom_bump(data=Clippers, aes(x=Season, y=Rk, group=Team), color="#1D428A") +
  geom_point(data=Clippers, aes(x=Season, y=Rk), color = "#1D428A", size = 4) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  labs(title="Kawhi's Journey in the Top Ranks", 
       subtitle="Leonard continues to help the <span style = 'color:black;'>Spurs</span>, <span style = 'color:#CE1141;'>Raptors</span> and <span style = 'color:#1D428A;'>Clippers</span> finish strong in the NBA's Regular Season.",
       y= "Rank", 
       x = "Season",
       caption="Source: Basketball-Reference.com | By Mason Dover") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position = "none"
    )









Toronto’s trade worked out! The Raptors finished second overall in the NBA. Leonard came into Toronto ready to win and succeeded.
In any basketball game, the offense and defense determine a win or loss. Since Kawhi has won a lot, how has he performed in the offense?
The Raptors traded away their leading scorer for Leonard. Toronto needed Kawhi to fill in the role and lead them to a championship.


Code
KawhiCareer <- read_csv("KawhiData - KawhiPlayerStats.csv")
KawhiTeams <- read_csv("KawhiData - KawhiTeams.csv")

KawhiSpecificTeams <- KawhiTeams |>
  filter(PRESENT == "YES") |>
  select(Season, Tm, PTS) |>
  rename(
    TeamPts = PTS
  )

KawhiBarTeams <-KawhiCareer |>
  inner_join(KawhiSpecificTeams) |>
  mutate(
    TeamSeason = paste(Tm, Season)
  ) |>
  select(TeamSeason, TeamPts, PTS) |>
  rename(
    Pts = PTS
  ) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols=ends_with("Pts"), 
    names_to="Type", 
    values_to="Pts")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=KawhiBarTeams, aes(x=reorder(TeamSeason, Pts), weight=Pts, fill=Type)) + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("red", "lightgrey")) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title="Leonard Finds Rhythm", 
       subtitle="Kawhi becomes a dual threat when his offensive efficiency improved with the Toronto Raptors.", 
       y= "Total Points", 
       x = "",
       caption="Source: Basketball-Reference.com | By Mason Dover") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position = "none"
    )









Until recently, Kawhi’s season with the Toronto Raptors was the most offensively efficient team in his career. Toronto scored 9,384 points that year, which is the most points scored in any Raptors season. Kawhi contributed 1,596 points to the franchise record.
Kawhi led the Raptors in scoring that year with an average of 26.6 points. Almost averaging 10 total points over the next player, Pascal Siakam, Leonard was a big asset on offense for the Raptors.
Now that Kawhi’s offensive skills have been determined, how was his defense with the Raptors?
Kawhi came into the Raptors with amazing defensive skills from the Spurs. The two-time Defensive Player of the Year wanted to shut down the court.


Code
Season2019 <- read_csv("NBAData - NBA2019Players.csv")

NBADefensePlayers <- Season2019 |>
  filter(Player == "Giannis Antetokounmpo" | Player == "Eric Bledsoe" | Player == "Paul George" | Player == "Rudy Gobert" | Player == "Marcus Smart" | Player == "Joel Embiid" | Player == "Draymond Green" | Player == "Jrue Holiday" | Player == "Kawhi Leonard" | Player == "Klay Thompson")

DefenseStats <- NBADefensePlayers |>
  select(Player, DRB, STL, BLK)

DefenseStats |> 
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    DRB = "Def Rebounds",
    STL = "Steals",
    BLK = "Blocks"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "The Claw Lockdowns the League",
    subtitle = "The Toronto Raptors relied on All-Defensive Second Team's, Kawhi Leonard, to win the NBA Championship."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Mason Dover  |  **Source:** Basketball-Reference.com")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=14)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#CE1141"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Kawhi Leonard")
  )









The Claw Lockdowns the League


The Toronto Raptors relied on All-Defensive Second Team's, Kawhi Leonard, to win the NBA Championship.


Player
Def Rebounds
Steals
Blocks




Giannis Antetokounmpo
739

Klay Thompson

By: Mason Dover | Source: Basketball-Reference.com









While Kawhi did not earn All-Defensive First Team, he was awarded for his defensive skills that year.
Leonard proved to be a dual threat on the court. The 2019 NBA Champion had a great all-around game that helped the Toronto Raptors win the league.
The potential Hall of Famer had a significant impact on the Raptors. Even though Leonard left the organization, no one can deny what he did for the Raptors.
